name: Song Blocks
tagline: A no-tech, toddler-friendly controller for Sonos using NFC tags
body:
### Welcome to Song Blocks
I built Song Blocks so my toddler could play music on the living room Sonos by himself.

Wood blocks containing NFC tags magnetically attach to a drawer face, behind which sits a Raspberry Pi and an NFC controller.  Each block's NFC tag is mapped to a song, which plays when the block attaches and stops when it is detached.  Each played song is tweeted at [@songblocks](https://twitter.com/songblocks).  

The primary design goal was to make the technology disappear completely: the final experience is organic, tactile and aural - and quite magical.  The blocks align and pull themselves to the drawer face, snapping on with a satisfying _clack!_.  Music fills the room until the block is prised away. [@songblocks](https://twitter.com/songblocks) silently records a history my son's listening habits.  It will be fun to graph it in a few months to see how his preferences have changed over time. 

![Blocks](https://www.dropbox.com/s/7ny63nauakkqr4p/blocks.JPG?dl=1)

### Technologies Used
* Raspberry Pi
* NFC controller board
* NFC tags
* Rare-earth magnets
* A simple Python script (~100 lines) that I wrote, hosted on GitHub [here](https://github.com/shawnrk/songblocks)
* Open-source Python libs: [SoCo](https://github.com/SoCo/SoCo) to talk to the Sonos, [nfcpy](https://launchpad.net/nfcpy) to talk to the NFC controller, [TweetPony](https://github.com/Mezgrman/TweetPony) to talk to Twitter

### The blocks
* 3/8" thick walnut boards were cut down to pieces measuring 1-1/2"x3-1/4" (two of these form each block)  
* Cavities were routed out for the NFC tag and magnets (they sit 3/16" below the outer surface).  Magnets were glued in.
![Adding NFC tags and gluing in the magnets](https://www.dropbox.com/s/ivab56cmj4c9a6c/factory.JPG?dl=1)


* The halves were then glued and clamped
![Clamping](https://www.dropbox.com/s/ullvmcmbyeu25km/press.JPG?dl=1)


* Each side was evened out by cutting off a very thin slice with a band saw
* The edges were given a 1/8" radius round-over with a router
* The sides and edges were sanded with 120 grit (the seam between the halves were rendered barely visible)
![Before & After](https://www.dropbox.com/s/ufv3jjwsialenos/squareround.JPG?dl=1)
![Before & After 2](https://www.dropbox.com/s/y5lrcd2twwp79yn/squareround2.JPG?dl=1)


* The numbers were imprinted with an ink stamp set and then burned in with a soldering iron
![Burn](https://www.dropbox.com/s/z3jzznzlrof9oyq/burn.JPG?dl=1)


* The wood has been left natural - no oil, sealant, etc.

### The drawer
* Cavities were routed out from the inside of the drawer face to place the magnets (they sit 3/16" below the outer surface)
* The NFC controller board is taped to the inside of the drawer face
* The Raspberry Pi just sits in the drawer, with its power cord running out the back
* The wires between the NFC controller and the Raspberry Pi connect UART Rx, Tx, +5v, and ground 

### The code
I haven't coded in over a decade and this is my first Python project.  So its ugly, but functional and pretty self-explanatory. The GitHub repo is [here](https://github.com/shawnrk/songblocks).
